Archangel

Let's discuss the results of the debate and decide who won it. I realize that Sarah Palin is a huge underdog and is hated by the Left because of her outsider status. But I'm pulling for her and hope that all of this negative press she has been inundated with hasn't destroyed her self confidence.
 
 The only thing I know for certain going into tonights debate is that the Leftists are betting on a dinosaur with Joe Biden, and I hope he shows his true colors, because that will insure a Palin victory.

post_info.post_title: Tonight's the VP Debate, Any Predictions?

daewoo

Hmmm. Predictions...
 
 Both canidates will get up there, dodge any difficult or important questions, toss out a bunch of worthless spin because it sounds good, then tomorrow both sides will claim that their candidate "won", despite the fact that all they gave were BS answer.
Penfold
Can Palin do that much? emoticon_rolleyes
T.Q

I'm watching it now. Palin seems incapable of actually answering a question:
 1) do you support benefits for same sex couples?
 She doesn't support redefining marriage-that wasn't the question. Biden stated he does support benefits for same sex couples.
 2) What exit strategy from Iraq do you support?
 She never gave an answer, just stated the surge was working, then stated Obama voted against supporting the troops. Biden outlined a clear exit strategy, and pointed out McCain voted against the same bill that Obama did. 
 
 She's done that at least 3-4 times that I've seen so far-stated that Obama voted for/against something, and Biden has pointed out McCain voted the exact same way.
daewoo

All things considered I think she did well. She did seem to dodge a lot of the questions and keep trying to steer back to the subjects that she had been better prepped for and voters actually see her as being knowledgeable about like energy. 
 
 Frankly I think her prep team screwed her by setting up a lot of "Obama voted against" without taking into account the fact that McCain voted the same way. 
 
 She also badly misused her script responses. When you prep for a political debate your prep teams gives you a bunch of "if you can fit this in use it" material. You could tell when she was using script responses and she used them ineffectively. An example would be when Biden explained why the troop funding bill had lost his support. The she comes back with the whole "I am an outsider and I dont understand this flip flopping stuff". Frankly she looked like an idiot. Biden had just spent 2 minutes explaining in idiot terms why he changed his mind. That was a script response and it was badly used.
 
 The whole "Family sitting aroudn the table" thing was also TERRIBLY used. Did her prep team not give her Bidens history?? 
 
 For the debate, Palin gets a B. Her prep team gets an F. 
 
 If I was scoring it as a formal debate, she would lose because she kept going off topic.
 
 As far as Biden goes, I think he performed as expected. Nobody watched the debate to see Biden. He has been in the game for 30 years. He has had plenty of experience.
Archangel

http://www1.pictures.gi.zimbio.com/Biden+Palin+Square+Off+VP+Debate+AChKDftKaTxl.jpg Bye bye barack & Joe.
 
 Like they said, this was Sarah's to lose tonight. And she won it big by remaining positive, being someone the average American can identify with and being someone who identified with the average american also. On personality and like-ability points she hit it out of the park, to use a baseball analogy and Biden was the baseball. His mouth was turned down which gave the impression that he was very nervous under the skin, where as she was light and airy and appeared very confident in her convictions.
 
 We can critique the substance of each person all day long, but until we've been on equally as large a stage, I think our personal preferences will get in the way.
T.Q

All things considered I think she did well. She did seem to dodge a lot of the questions and keep trying to steer back to the subjects that she had been better prepped for and voters actually see her as being knowledgeable about like energy. 

 Agreed, she did much better than I expected.
 
 
Frankly I think her prep team screwed her by setting up a lot of "Obama voted against" without taking into account the fact that McCain voted the same way. 

 Yeah, every example I can remember, Biden came back and pointed out McCain voted the same way
 
 
An example would be when Biden explained why the troop funding bill had lost his support. The she comes back with the whole "I am an outsider and I dont understand this flip flopping stuff". Frankly she looked like an idiot. Biden had just spent 2 minutes explaining in idiot terms why he changed his mind. That was a script response and it was badly used.

 Agreed. That was a horrible response after Biden's simplistic explanation.
 
 
The whole "Family sitting aroudn the table" thing was also TERRIBLY used. Did her prep team not give her Bidens history?? 

 Yeah, as soon as she started with that, I cringed. Biden's response was much more restrained than I was expecting. He could have absolutely nailed her right there. 
 
 
For the debate, Palin gets a B. Her prep team gets an F. 

 I'd say a C for her. She didn't give many straight responses, kept trying to divert back to her comfort zones, and busted out the "folksy" stories too much. 
 
 
If I was scoring it as a formal debate, she would lose because she kept going off topic.

 Yep
 
 
As far as Biden goes, I think he performed as expected. Nobody watched the debate to see Biden. He has been in the game for 30 years. He has had plenty of experience.

 The only complaint I had about Biden was I wish he had pointed out her meandering more and called her to task for not directly answering questions. I think he was told to go easy on her for fear of a backlash for being "sexist".
daewoo

http://www1.pictures.gi.zimbio.com/Biden+Palin+Square+Off+VP+Debate+AChKDftKaTxl.jpg Bye bye barack & Joe.
 
 Like they said, this was Sarah's to lose tonight. And she won it big by remaining positive, being someone the average American can identify with and being someone who identified with the average american also. On personality and like-ability points she hit it out of the park, to use a baseball analogy and Biden was the baseball. His mouth was turned down which gave the impression that he was very nervous under the skin, where as she was light and airy and appeared very confident in her convictions.
 
 We can critique the substance of each person all day long, but until we've been on equally as large a stage, I think our personal preferences will get in the way.

 
 Did it bother you at all as an obvious supporter that she refused to answer any difficult questions?
daewoo

Agreed, she did much better than I expected.
 Yeah, every example I can remember, Biden came back and pointed out McCain voted the same way

 
 IMO that was a HUGE mistake. It was almost like she threw mud and hit McCain in the back of the head. In that kind of forum that is EXTREMELY dangerous because Biden had the chance to explain why he and Obama voted the way they did. Basically it is like she went "you are terrible because you voted against troop funding", Biden comes back with "So did McCain, here is why WE did it", but you never hear about why McCain did it, so he just stays labeled as a terrible person who did not support the troops. 
 
 
Yeah, as soon as she started with that, I cringed. Biden's response was much more restrained than I was expecting. He could have absolutely nailed her right there. 

 
 IMO Biden screwed up by handling her with kiddie gloves. 
 
 
I'd say a C for her. She didn't give many straight responses, kept trying to divert back to her comfort zones, and busted out the "folksy" stories too much. 

 
 I think she did better than a C. Her prep team must have been drunk, though. 
 
 
The only complaint I had about Biden was I wish he had pointed out her meandering more and called her to task for not directly answering questions. I think he was told to go easy on her for fear of a backlash for being "sexist".

 
 Agree. This was his worst mistake. It would have been easy to get past the potential downfalls. It could have been as simple as starting with "I respect your intelligence too much to play softball here....."
snakespit

I think she comes off well as far as "of the people", but that can only carry her so far. She seems well versed, or at least well instructed on energy and voting records, but her lack of experience foreign policy and the economy shines through. She seemed like she was simply giving canned answers to questions that called for more vivid explanations, and did seem to dodge a few questions. 
 
 All in all I would say that she did better than expected, but I still think Biden came off as the more knowledgeable and experienced candidate. When I look at a VP candidate, I ask myself which I would feel more comfortable taking over the country if the president were to be incapacitated. In this case, I would definately say Biden makes me far more comfortable. That being said...I don't plan on voting for either McCain or Obama as they both scare the hell out of me as our future president and I don't feel that I can give my vote in good conscience to either of them. I refuse to pick the lesser of 2 evils when it comes to our leaders. I think as Americans, we deserve better than the garbage that we keep putting up for vote.
daewoo

I think she comes off well as far as "of the people", but that can only carry her so far. She seems well versed, or at least well instructed on energy and voting records, but her lack of experience foreign policy and the economy shines through. She seemed like she was simply giving canned answers to questions that called for more vivid explanations, and did seem to dodge a few questions.

 Agreed 100% ++good.
 
 I despise both candidates equally and both of them are absolute nightmares. Hopefully they will both die horribly on the way to the next debate and we can pick some new candidates.
 
 I saw an interesting poll today. Remember Ron Paul...that lunatic who kept saying the economy was going to crash, banks were going to fail, and the level of debt in the US was going to screw us all? Apparently 80% of Americans would be willing to vote for him today. 
 
 Go figure.
snakespit

Agreed 100% ++good.
 
 I despise both candidates equally and both of them are absolute nightmares. Hopefully they will both die horribly on the way to the next debate and we can pick some new candidates.
 
 I saw an interesting poll today. Remember Ron Paul...that lunatic who kept saying the economy was going to crash, banks were going to fail, and the level of debt in the US was going to screw us all? Apparently 80% of Americans would be willing to vote for him today. 
 
 Go figure.

 
 I never understood why Paul didn't run as an independent. Paul makes far more sense than any of the other talking heads in both the Democratic or Republican parties. Ron Paul would get my vote in a heartbeat.
daewoo

I never understood why Paul didn't run as an independent. Paul makes far more sense than any of the other talking heads in both the Democratic or Republican parties. Ron Paul would get my vote in a heartbeat.

 
 IMO it was because he failed to grasp the fact that while there are PLENTY of conservatives out there who would have voted for them, the republican party has pretty much been taken over by militant liberals and closet fascists, and an actual conservative can stomach neither one. 
 
 IMO Paul would have won the presidency in a heartbeat, but could not have won the primary in either party. He would have won the presidency by pulling 40% of the republican vote and 40% of the democratic vote. There are a lot of democrats out there who franjly have become fiscal conservatives. He also would have been able to pick up the anti war vote from the democrats. Same goes for the republican side. He would have appealed to true conservatives who, in most cases, are also anti war (at least this war). 
 
 He was trying to take back the republican party, which was pretty much just an idealistic move.
applemacin
Both did well more than I expected. Word for the day: maverick.
T.Q

Both did well more than I expected. Word for the day: maverick.

 
 I don't think we can use the word "maverick" anymore. Palin used it every second sentence, it's all used up now.
 
 Daewoo, Snakespit (is it Snake spit or snakes pit?), just curious about your views on Obama. I haven't heard too much negative about him other than the rumours/innuendo from the partisan wackos. What about him do you find detrimental?
snakespit

IMO it was because he failed to grasp the fact that while there are PLENTY of conservatives out there who would have voted for them, the republican party has pretty much been taken over by militant liberals and closet fascists, and an actual conservative can stomach neither one. 
 
 IMO Paul would have won the presidency in a heartbeat, but could not have won the primary in either party. He would have won the presidency by pulling 40% of the republican vote and 40% of the democratic vote. There are a lot of democrats out there who franjly have become fiscal conservatives. He also would have been able to pick up the anti war vote from the democrats. Same goes for the republican side. He would have appealed to true conservatives who, in most cases, are also anti war (at least this war). 
 
 He was trying to take back the republican party, which was pretty much just an idealistic move.

 
 It seems to me that the majority of republicans today are akin to the democrats of 50-60 years ago, and the majority of democrats today are blazing their own path towards a socialist utopia. The problem is, Americans still think in terms of conservative and liberal when they think of republicans and democrats. These labels are just not accurate anymore. 
 
 IMO, there has never been a better time for an independent candidate to step forward and win the White House. It seems that everywhere you turn during this election they shout the word change, yet all I can hear is status quo. Might as well flip a coin between Obama and McCain...I don't think it will matter that much.
snakespit

I don't think we can use the word "maverick" anymore. Palin used it every second sentence, it's all used up now.
 
 Daewoo, Snakespit (is it Snake spit or snakes pit?), just curious about your views on Obama. I haven't heard too much negative about him other than the rumours/innuendo from the partisan wackos. What about him do you find detrimental?

 
 Snake spit...and thanks for asking. 
 
 Frankly, because he fundamentaly believes that the government needs to save the American people. I fundamentaly believe that the American people need to be saved from our government. 
 
 The substance of their individual policies don't really matter to me. It is this difference in fundamental belief that will not allow me to support either candidate.
Archangel

I think she comes off well as far as "of the people", but that can only carry her so far. She seems well versed, or at least well instructed on energy and voting records, but her lack of experience foreign policy and the economy shines through. She seemed like she was simply giving canned answers to questions that called for more vivid explanations, and did seem to dodge a few questions. 
 
 All in all I would say that she did better than expected, but I still think Biden came off as the more knowledgeable and experienced candidate. When I look at a VP candidate, I ask myself which I would feel more comfortable taking over the country if the president were to be incapacitated. In this case, I would definately say Biden makes me far more comfortable. That being said...I don't plan on voting for either McCain or Obama as they both scare the hell out of me as our future president and I don't feel that I can give my vote in good conscience to either of them. I refuse to pick the lesser of 2 evils when it comes to our leaders. I think as Americans, we deserve better than the garbage that we keep putting up for vote.

 
 The problem with the perception of Bidens knowledge is, he's seen as a Washington political insider who can't be trusted at all. I agree that he is more knowledgeable though, but he ought to have a better grasp on specifics after 36 years in Washington. The question is, will he truly represent the best interests of the people or is he viewed by the voters as more of the same? I think he is definitely considered an entrenched insider who has all of the political connections which bypass the best interests of the people, in favor of working with the lobbyists, special interests and the typical unseen powers that be whom we the people don't even know the names of. 
 
 
I never understood why Paul didn't run as an independent. Paul makes far more sense than any of the other talking heads in both the Democratic or Republican parties. Ron Paul would get my vote in a heartbeat.

 
 It's because in either 2001 or 03 the political insiders actually wrote laws and formed monetary roadblocks which pretty much guaranteed that third parties will never again be allowed to get a foot hold in American politics. I remember it happening but I can't remember the definitive term to describe it, but that is why we haven't seen a third party candidate in any election since 2000. Whatever they did was very effective in shutting third parties out of the process. 
 
 But I agree with you about Ron Paul. He got short shrift through out this campaign and was just never to ignite the masses or maybe it was just impossible to get an accurate tally of all the support he really garnered. Because where ever I turned people liked him, yet he only appeared as a blip on the political radar. 
 
 
It seems to me that the majority of republicans today are akin to the democrats of 50-60 years ago, and the majority of democrats today are blazing their own path towards a socialist utopia. The problem is, Americans still think in terms of conservative and liberal when they think of republicans and democrats. These labels are just not accurate anymore. 
 
 IMO, there has never been a better time for an independent candidate to step forward and win the White House. It seems that everywhere you turn during this election they shout the word change, yet all I can hear is status quo. Might as well flip a coin between Obama and McCain...I don't think it will matter that much.

 
 Regarding the first paragraph, I completely agree again with your definition of the political landscape. As for the second paragraph, I also agree with the hunger of the voters for a third party, but I return to the built in road blocks for one to be allowed into the process.
snakespit

The problem with the perception of Bidens knowledge is, he's seen as a Washington political insider who can't be trusted at all. I agree that he is more knowledgeable though, but he ought to have a better grasp on specifics after 36 years in Washington. The question is, will he truly represent the best interests of the people or is he viewed by the voters as more of the same? I think he is definitely considered an entrenched insider who has all of the political connections which bypass the best interests of the people, in favor of working with the lobbyists, special interests and the typical unseen powers that be whom we the people don't even know the names of. 

 In my opinion, you can use the names Biden and McCain interchangeably in this sentence and it still makes sense to me. 
 
 
 
 
It's because in either 2001 or 03 the political insiders actually wrote laws and formed monetary roadblocks which pretty much guaranteed that third parties will never again be allowed to get a foot hold in American politics. I remember it happening but I can't remember the definitive term to describe it, but that is why we haven't seen a third party candidate in any election since 2000. Whatever they did was very effective in shutting third parties out of the process. 

 They have made it harder, but it is not out of the question...yet. There are a lot of hoops to jump through, but the American people tend to jump from time to time. Wait till this depression sets in.
 
 
But I agree with you about Ron Paul. He got short shrift through out this campaign and was just never to ignite the masses or maybe it was just impossible to get an accurate tally of all the support he really garnered. Because where ever I turned people liked him, yet he only appeared as a blip on the political radar. 

 It's partially his fault. His attempt to run on the republican ticket, and unfortunately sealed his fate before a single vote was counted. Ron Paul does not espouse the current republican party in any way. He respresents a Herbert Hoover kind of guy. Warned it was coming, had a plan to do something about it, and probably would not take no for an answer. Well, historically things seem to be repeating themselves, because Hoovers warnings were not heard. So the questions now are these: Who will play the role of FDR? MaCain or Obama? McCain seems a better fit for the part, but that is probably not a good thing anyway. And, will we need a Truman?
jitobear

Hmmm. Predictions...
 
 Both canidates will get up there, dodge any difficult or important questions, toss out a bunch of worthless spin because it sounds good, then tomorrow both sides will claim that their candidate "won", despite the fact that all they gave were BS answer.

 
 
 Yep - that was pretty much it. I felt Palin was more personable and Biden more knowledgable. The moderator seemed to have the best brains of the lot. The whole thing was rather underwhelming.
 
 Biden has an awful nice smile though - and she sure is purty....
isly ilwott

It would likely take the average person months to verify all of the answers' statistics and statements given. One commentator did point out that one of Biden's claims that McCain voted the same as Obama did was incorrect.
 
 I think both of them did fairly well. I do remember yesterday some liberal on a talk show saying that he hoped Palin would break down and cry. She didn't...but Biden did get all choked up when he mentioned his own family. I'll forgive him for that.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Tonight's the VP Debate, Any Predictions?
